WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


A noise-tolerant human–machine interface based on deep learning-enhanced wearable sensors
Source: Nature    Published: 2025-11-17 10:15:20

Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript. Advertisement Nature Sensors (2025)Cite this article Wearable human–machine interfaces with inertial measurement units (IMUs) are widely applied across healthcare, robotics and interactive technologies. However, extracting reliable signals remains challenging owing to motion artefacts in real-world environments. Here we present a human–machine interface capable of tolerating diverse motion artefacts through deep learning-enhanced wearable sensors. The system integrates a six-channel IMU, an electromyography module, a Bluetooth microcontroller unit and a stretchable battery, enabling wireless capture and transmission of gesture signals. A convolutional neural network trained on a composite dataset of gestures and motion artefacts extracts robust signals, while parameter-based transfer learning improves the generalizability of the network across users. A sliding-window approach converts the extracted gesture signals into real-time, continuous control of a robotic arm during dynamic activities such as running, high-frequency vibration, posture changes, oceanic wave motion and combinations of these. This work demonstrates the potential of wearable human–machine interfaces for complex real-world applications. You have full access to this article via your institution. Wearable devices have shown great promise in various applications, such as continuous health monitoring1,2,3, energy harvesting4,5,6 and storage7,8,9, and human–machine interfaces10,11,12. Wearable inertial measurement units (IMUs) that can capture gesture signals have proven to be particularly valuable for virtual and augmented reality13, non-verbal communication14, physiological monitoring15, sports rehabilitation16 and robotic control17. However, gesture signals are inevitably confounded by motion artefacts in real-world applications (Supplementary Note 1). Such motion artefacts can arise from environmental activities such as walking, running or sitting in moving vehicles, from the changing orientations of the IMUs owing to the gravity vector (Supplementary Fig. 1) or from combinations of these. The motion artefacts may exhibit similar frequencies to those of gesture signals, or different frequencies but larger magnitudes that overwhelm them, or may vary among individuals. Hence, recovering gesture signals amid these motion artefacts is a major challenge18,19,20. Existing methods for mitigating motion artefacts in IMUs can be broadly categorized into hardware- and software-based approaches (Supplementary Note 2). For hardware-based approaches, reducing the device thickness or enhancing the adhesion between the device and the skin can help minimize motion artefacts caused by relative displacement at the skin–sensor interface21. Although this method is effective in biopotential measurement, it is less effective for IMUs, which inherently capture unintentional disturbances during body movements. In addition, incorporating additional sets of IMUs can eliminate common motion artefacts. Specifically, a dual-IMU configuration placed at adjacent anatomical sites (for example, the suprasternal notch and sternal manubrium) can record identical motion artefacts induced by body movements while recording physiological signals of different magnitudes (for example, respiration and heart rates)22. However, this approach is applicable to only specific locations and is not suitable for most other regions. A multi-IMU configuration (for example, on the torso and limbs) has also been explored to derive differential signals eliminating common motion artefacts23, but this approach suffers from sensor misalignment, asynchronization and inconsistent patterns of motion artefacts across different body segments. For software-based approaches, methods including bandpass filtering24, wavelet transform25 and principal component analysis26 can isolate signals without requiring prior knowledge of motion artefact characteristics. However, the effectiveness of these techniques relies on the assumption that the signal (for example, biopotential, respiration rate or heart rate) exhibits distinct spectral and spatial characteristics from motion artefacts. This assumption does not apply to gesture signals in IMUs, which share similar characteristics to motion artefacts. Moreover, these methods are not well suited for real-time gesture recognition involving multiple gesture types owing to their high computational cost. In addition, motion artefacts can be eliminated by leveraging prior knowledge of their characteristics. Adaptive signal decomposition separates signals into constituent components characterized by specific frequency bands or distinct features, enabling selective removal of motion artefacts18, whereas adaptive filtering uses a correlated reference to iteratively subtract motion artefacts27. However, both methods are computationally intensive28, require case-specific parameter tuning29 and suffer from edge effects30. In addition, machine learning models have been trained to filter motion artefacts, but these models have only been tested on simulated Gaussian noise31, which does not incorporate characteristics of real-world motion artefacts, such as complex sources, varying intensities and temporal misalignment between signals and motion artefacts. Here we demonstrate unprecedented deep learning-enhanced wearable sensors that accurately recognize gestures despite the presence of diverse real-world motion artefacts (Fig. 1a and Supplementary Note 3). The sensors comprise a six-channel IMU, an electromyography (EMG) module, a Bluetooth microcontroller unit and a customized battery, all mounted on a fabric substrate. The sensors feature a compact multilayered architecture (1.8 × 4.5 cm2, with a thickness of 2 mm) with >20% stretchability. We trained a convolutional neural network (CNN) on a composite dataset containing gesture signals and motion artefacts from various sources. Then the collected IMU data were processed by the trained CNN, enabling accurate gesture recognition even when the individual was running, changing postures, experiencing high-frequency vibrations, floating in oceanic waves, or encountering combinations of these conditions. Moreover, we applied transfer learning to streamline the training process for new individuals. In addition, a sliding-window mechanism realizes continuous gesture recognition. The recognized gestures, combined with digitally filtered EMG signals, were used to precisely control a robotic arm in real time. a, Schematics illustrating the six-channel IMU, EMG module, Bluetooth microcontroller unit (MCU) and stretchable battery. Gesture signals containing various motion artefacts are captured by the IMU and processed using a deep learning model. Acc, accelerometer; Gyro, gyroscope. The processed results are combined with digitally filtered EMG signals to control a robotic arm. ADC, analogue-to-digital converter. b, Photograph of the sensors and exploded view of its multilayered architecture. The lower-right inset shows the battery configuration, where Zn and Ag2O function as anode and cathode, respectively, PVA hydrogel as the electrolyte, a TiO2 layer as the separator and Ag as the current collector. Zn, Ag2O, TiO2 and Ag were mixed with stretchable binders. The entire battery is encased within SEBS. The upper-right inset shows the tri-layered EMG electrode. InAMP, instrumentation amplifier; VIA, vertical interconnect access. c, Capacity cyclic test of the stretchable Zn/Ag2O battery during freestanding, bending and stretching states. Over 60 cycles, the battery capacity maintained at ~25 mAh. The coulombic efficiency remained at nearly 100% throughout the entire process. d, Received signal strength indicator (RSSI) of the Bluetooth signal as a function of working distance. The graph presents the mean values, with error bars indicating the standard deviation (n = 15 independent RSSI measurements at each distance). e, Thermal image of the sensors. The dashed frame specifies the device area. After continuous operation for 30 min under ambient conditions, the peak temperature of the sensors stabilized at 27.7 °C. Source data The sensors were designed with four layers32 (Fig. 1b and Supplementary Fig. 2). The first layer was a battery bonded onto a fabric substrate. Inside the battery, 2 cells were connected in series to provide an output voltage of ~3.1 V (Extended Data Fig. 1 and Methods). After 60 charge–discharge cycles, the battery capacity maintained at ~25 mAh, even under bending and stretching33 (Supplementary Note 4). The coulombic efficiency remained at ~100% (Fig. 1c and Methods). The second, third and fourth layers formed the circuit (Methods). The second layer incorporated an antenna-matching unit and an amplifier module for EMG collection. We used tri-layered EMG electrodes34 (Supplementary Note 5): the bottom was an elastomer substrate providing structural support; the middle was an island-bridge structured stretchable Cu35, which ensured robust bonding with the circuit and reduced the electrode impedance (Supplementary Fig. 3); the top was an elastomer doped with carbon nanotubes (CNTs)36, which protected the Cu from abrasion and corrosion (Methods). The third layer integrated a six-channel IMU to acquire gesture signals and a Bluetooth microcontroller unit for signal processing and wireless transmission to a backend receiver. We measured the Bluetooth signal intensity using the received signal strength indicator in an open environment at varying distances (Methods). The signals remained strong and stable (decreased from −46 dBm to −96 dBm) up to 20 m (Fig. 1d). The highest temperature within the sensors after 30 min of continuous operation was observed at the Bluetooth microcontroller unit, reaching only 27.7 °C (Fig. 1e). During prolonged wear (~1 h), the skin temperature under actual wearing conditions remained stable at 34.5 °C, confirming the safety of the sensors for wearable use (Supplementary Fig. 4 and Methods). The fourth layer housed two crystal oscillators that generated clock signals to synchronize all sensors (Supplementary Figs. 5 and 6, Supplementary Table 1 and Supplementary Note 6). To establish connections between the different layers, we used vertical interconnect accesses to ensure mechanical robustness while minimizing constraints on stretchability32 (Methods). The circuit was cyclically stretchable to ~20% uniaxially (Extended Data Fig. 2) and ~20% biaxially, maintaining stable signal transmission without noticeable plastic deformation (Extended Data Fig. 3). The total power consumption of all sensors was 15 mW, and the customized battery could power them for >4 h (Supplementary Fig. 7 and Methods). The sensors could acquire six channels of IMU and one of EMG. The IMU, operating at a sampling rate of 100 Hz per channel, incorporated a 3-channel accelerometer along the x, y and z axes and a 3-channel gyroscope along the roll, yaw and pitch axes. We recorded the IMU signals from 19 forearm gestures when the individual was sitting, with each gesture lasting ~1 s (Fig. 2a). In addition, we collected three representative types of motion artefact, including baseline and morphological variations in IMU signals during transitions from sitting to lying (Fig. 2b and Supplementary Fig. 8), high-frequency vibrations induced by a massage gun (Fig. 2c and Supplementary Fig. 9) and running with natural forearm swinging (Fig. 2d). Concurrently, the EMG captured muscle signals with a sampling rate of 1,000 Hz from two hand gestures: grasping and releasing (Fig. 2e, Supplementary Fig. 10 and Supplementary Note 7). The signal-to-noise ratio of the EMG decreased from 67 dB (sitting) to 55 dB (running) and 29 dB (vibration), but retained sufficient fidelity to enable differentiation of muscle activities (Supplementary Fig. 11). Both IMU and EMG signals showed high temporal consistency and low noise level across various environmental conditions37 (Supplementary Figs. 12–14). a, Depiction of 19 gesture signals when the individual is sitting. The sensors mounted on the forearm capture each gesture within 1 s. The first gesture is to keep the forearm relatively level, while the other 18 gestures vary in angle, speed and direction, and thus distinct IMU signals. The grey arrow shows the upwards and downwards forearm rotation, the blue arrow shows the leftwards and rightwards forearm rotation, and the red arrow shows the wrist rotation. b, Motion artefacts of the same 19 gestures collected when the individual is lying down. The markedly different IMU waveforms arise from the orientation shifts of the IMU relative to gravity. c, Motion artefacts when the forearm is stimulated with a high-frequency massage gun. d, Motion artefacts generated by the natural swinging of the forearm and overall body movement during running. e, Filtered EMG signals during hand grasping and releasing. The red curve represents the root mean square of the filtered signals. Source data We generated a composite dataset to extract gesture signals from motion artefacts (Fig. 3a and Supplementary Note 8). The dataset included forearm gesture signals (20 signals per gesture during sitting and 20 for lying down) (Supplementary Note 9) and superimposed signals obtained by adding strong motion artefacts (under the highest available running speed and maximum vibration intensity and frequency) to gesture signals (Extended Data Fig. 4, Supplementary Fig. 15 and Methods). Motion artefacts at different stages (that is, starting and ending points) produced varying waveforms. Therefore, motion artefacts from different stages were added to gesture signals to account for diverse conditions. a, Schematics of the process used to construct the training dataset. The composite dataset was assembled by superimposing diverse motion artefacts onto gesture signals. b, Comparative analysis of recall values across different deep learning models. The CNN shows superior accuracy with the highest recall value. The graph presents the mean values, with error bars indicating the standard deviations (n = 15 independent test results). FCN, fully connected neural network; RNN, recurrent neural network. c, Architecture of the customized CNN. It includes three convolutional layers, three max-pooling layers and three fully connected (FC) layers, with cross-entropy as the loss function. d, Schematics of the transfer learning process, which features two major steps. First, the model is pre-trained on a dataset from five individuals. Second, the pre-trained model adapts to a new individual by fine-tuning, which involves training the convolutional layers at a lower learning rate with a smaller dataset from the new individual. e, Confusion matrices of the results before and after transfer learning. The minimum recognition accuracy of the 19 gestures improved from 51% to 92%. f, Schematics of the sliding-window mechanism. The window size is 1 s, with a sliding step of 0.25 s. Each segmented signal serves as an individual input, generating a separate prediction. Source data We trained and compared three deep-learning networks using the composite dataset and evaluated their performance based on the confusion matrix of the test outcomes. These models included a fully connected neural network as a reference, a recurrent neural network based on long short-term memory (Supplementary Figs. 16 and 17) and a CNN based on LeNet-5 (Supplementary Note 10). The CNN achieved the highest recall (>0.92), precision (>0.93), F1 score (>0.94) and specificity (>0.99), demonstrating superior performance in gesture recognition (Fig. 3b, Supplementary Fig. 18 and Supplementary Note 11). We customized the CNN to match the signal dimensions and optimize the performance in this study (Fig. 3c). At the input, six-channel IMU signals were reshaped into a single channel and passed through a one-dimensional convolutional layer with 16 kernels, resulting in 16 channels of signal representations. These were then summarized by a max-pooling layer. The process was repeated with subsequent convolutional layers using 32 and 64 kernels, each followed by max-pooling for hierachical feature summarization. Finally, the output was flattened and routed through three fully connected layers to derive the final predictions. We selected the commonly used cross-entropy as the loss function to evaluate the randomness dissimilarity between the model predictions and ground truth38 (Supplementary Note 12). During these training and validation phases, the accuracy of the CNN converged to ~1 and its loss to ~0, confirming the absence of overfitting and the appropriateness of the selected kernels and loss function (Supplementary Fig. 19). To further evaluate the model's robustness to unseen, real-world disturbances, we tested the system under two other running speeds and two other vibration intensities and frequencies without additional training. The recognition accuracy remained consistently high across all conditions (>94%), confirming the robustness of the model to unseen, real-world disturbances (Supplementary Fig. 20). Individual variations in gesture signals (Supplementary Fig. 21) and motion artefacts (Supplementary Fig. 22), induce discrepancies between the training and testing datasets, thereby reducing the model accuracy for new individuals. We therefore applied parameter-based transfer learning to enhance the model's generalizability39. We first trained the model on the composite dataset using a learning rate of 0.01, which controlled the convolutional layers and fully connected layers. Then, we transferred the model and fine-tuned it with varying numbers of shots (that is, the number of signals from each gesture) from the new individual (Supplementary Note 13). During fine-tuning process, we used a lower learning rate of 0.001 for the convolutional layers to retain the pre-trained signal representations (Fig. 3d and Supplementary Note 14). We evaluated the efficiency of the transfer learning process by testing 100 new signals (that is, unused in the training dataset) per gesture (Extended Data Fig. 5 and Methods). The results showed that transfer learning with only 2 shots per gesture (one recorded while sitting and one while lying down, as opposed to the 40 shots required during the initial training phase) was sufficient for a new individual. The transfer learning improved the minimum recognition accuracy across all 19 types of gesture from >51% to >92% (Fig. 3e). The time taken to collect motion artefacts from the new individual was also reduced from ~2 min to ~6 s (Supplementary Fig. 23). To achieve continuous gesture recognition, the acquired signals should be constantly fed into the CNN for prediction. Hence, we applied a sliding-window mechanism40, where the window contained signals from either a single gesture or two consecutive gestures. We selected a window length of 1 s to match the duration of each gesture and a sliding step size of 0.25 s to balance the computational load and the overlap between consecutive windows (Fig. 3f). A larger step size could cause feature loss, whereas a smaller one could slow down the prediction rate (Supplementary Note 15). When the sliding-window transitions between gestures, scenarios may arise where the window contains signals from two consecutive gestures. Therefore, we generated training signals using various consecutive gesture combinations. Rather than repeatedly performing such transitions manually, we simplified the process by concatenating individual superimposed gesture signals (that is, connecting two signals end-to-end) to simulate consecutive gestures. The sliding window was then applied to these concatenated signals, and each window was labelled to the gesture occupying more than 50% of its duration (Extended Data Fig. 6). A similar concatenation process was performed for signals recorded while lying down (Supplementary Fig. 24). This approach yielded 46,930 segmented signals for 19 gestures (Methods). Although many studies have achieved high accuracy in gesture recognition using IMU and EMG with various degrees of freedom41,42,43, these approaches require the user to remain stationary, because signals are inevitably impacted by motion artefacts. We achieved comparable recognition performance even in the presence of substantial motion artefacts (Supplementary Fig. 25 and Supplementary Note 16). The latency between the gesture and the robotic arm's action was ~1.3 s, owing to the time required to capture sufficient data points for initial gesture recognition and the intrinsic response delay of the robotic arm (Fig. 4a). However, because the gesture recognition was performed continuously using the sliding-window mechanism, the robotic arm executed sequential actions without interruption. Errors might arise when the sliding window contained two consecutive gesture signals with similar proportions. To solve this problem, the robotic arm was programmed to execute an action only after receiving three sequential identical predictions (Supplementary Fig. 26). Moreover, we implemented a drop-out mechanism by abandoning the fourth identical prediction (if present) to prevent redundant robotic actions when there were two consecutive identical gestures. Simultaneously, grasping and releasing of the robotic gripper were controlled by calculating the root mean square of the EMG signals and comparing it with a predefined threshold (Supplementary Fig. 27 and Methods). a, Schematics of controlling the robotic arm. The individual continuously performs gestures. The gesture signals are wirelessly transmitted to a backend station with a delay of ~1 ms by Bluetooth69. A sliding-window segments the gesture signals continuously after acquiring the first gesture signal, and does not segment the signal when there are not enough data points (<1 s). An online CNN model takes ~1 ms to generate a prediction for each segmented signal. Upon receiving 3 sequential predictions (~3 ms), the robotic arm responds (~275 ms) and executes the corresponding action. b, Demonstration of the individual controlling the robotic arm to transfer liquid while running on a treadmill. The IMU signals from the individual's forearm, though intertwined with motion artefacts, are processed to control the robotic arm precisely. When the root mean square of the EMG signals surpasses a predefined threshold, the robotic arm grasps the vial. Source data When the individual was running, the motion artefacts substantially distorted the accelerometer and gyroscope signals. The robotic arm experienced substantial unwanted vibrations without a deep learning algorithm (Supplementary Video 1). However, when equipped with the CNN trained on the composite dataset, the robotic arm executed the intended actions precisely. We successfully controlled the robotic arm to transfer liquid from a vial to a beaker (Fig. 4b and Supplementary Video 2). Similarly, precise control was maintained when the forearm was subjected to high-frequency vibrations (Extended Data Fig. 7 and Supplementary Video 3), orientation changes (Extended Data Fig. 8 and Supplementary Video 4) or combinations of these motion artefacts (Extended Data Figs. 9 and 10 and Supplementary Videos 5 and 6). Moreover, we conducted additional characterizations using real gesture signals collected under motion artefacts (versus those obtained by superimposing motion artefacts with gesture signals for training), which showed >93% accuracy in robotic arm control (Supplementary Fig. 28). Human–machine interfaces have been used by divers to control underwater robots for target tracking44, marine data collection45, shipwreck inspection46 and rescue operations47. However, in aquatic environments, IMUs record signals not only from the diver's gestures but also from the intricate dynamics of sea waves48, which vary substantially with wave parameters (for example, wavelength and height). Such wave-induced interferences can distort the diver's gesture signals, challenging the reliable operation of IMUs. We trained the CNN with a composite dataset that included diverse sea-wave motions. The training dataset was originally collected in San Diego Mission Bay (Fig. 5a). However, owing to the bay's enclosed nature (as opposed to an open oceanic environment), the amplitude of the sea waves remained low, and the influence on gesture signals was negligible (Supplementary Fig. 29). Furthermore, data acquisition on certain days limited sets of sea-wave parameters. We therefore used the Scripps Ocean–Atmosphere Research Simulator, an instrument for studying oceanic states, to acquire motion artefacts generated by various sea waves (Fig. 5b, Supplementary Fig. 30 and Supplementary Video 7). Because different wave parameters influence wave behaviour49 (Supplementary Fig. 31, Supplementary Table 2 and Supplementary Note 17), we systematically varied wavelength and wave height to represent a broad range of sea-wave conditions (Supplementary Figs. 32 and 33 and Methods), and eventually assembled an extensive dataset for each gesture. a, Photograph of an individual wearing the sensors for the collection of motion artefacts from San Diego Mission Bay. b, Collection of sea-wave motion artefacts at the Scripps Ocean–Atmosphere Research Simulator. By adjusting the simulator's settings, a range of sea-wave patterns can be created, allowing the sensors to capture diverse signal variations induced by sea waves. c, Offline demonstration incorporating sea-wave motion artefacts. The collected sea-wave motion artefacts are superimposed on gesture signals as input for the CNN. Source data After training the model with this dataset, we conducted an offline demonstration simulating a diver directing a robotic arm while floating in the ocean. When tested on the IMU signals superimposed with simulated sea-wave interference, the CNN consistently generated accurate commands for the robotic arm actions (Fig. 5c and Supplementary Fig. 34), with recall, precision, specificity and F1 score all approaching ~1 on the test dataset (Supplementary Fig. 35). The presence of seawater offered a unique advantage by reducing the electrode–skin impedance50, thereby enhancing the EMG signal quality (Supplementary Fig. 36). The sensors' architecture in this study features a multilayered, stretchable circuit design, allowing for a uniform and efficient spatial arrangement of components32, with a high degree of integration of electronics, EMG electrodes and battery. The sensors leverage a deep-learning model trained on a composite dataset, which demonstrates strong tolerance against a broad range of motion artefacts, enabling continuous and accurate robotic control under diverse real-world scenarios. There remain multiple opportunities to further improve this technology. First, the system is currently designed to recognize gestures lasting 1 s, which is suboptimal for gestures whose durations deviate largely from this window (Supplementary Note 18). To address this problem, a potential solution would be to incorporate an additional machine learning model for signal segmentation to dynamically identify the onset and termination of each gesture. The window could also be shortened to reduce latency by minimizing the time required to acquire a complete input segment, thereby enabling faster response. In this case, a more complex CNN architecture (for example, deeper networks or larger kernel sizes) would be required to extract discriminative features from shorter signals. To further enhance feature extraction, it is also feasible to integrate a squeeze-and-excitation attention mechanism51, which can prioritize key features while minimizing the influence of irrelevant ones, such as motion artefacts (Supplementary Note 19). Second, the current system is primarily designed to recognize single-axis and isolated gestures, which simplifies the recognition task and thus enhances model accuracy. To further improve performance and efficiency in recognizing more complex gestures, future work could explore the implementation of multi-parallel deep learning models (for example, with each model dedicated to recognizing gestures along a specific axis). This multi-model architecture would allow parallel processing of any type of signal, thereby enabling simultaneous multi-axis gesture recognition. Third, the sensors have a limited underwater communication range (<30 cm with a received signal strength indicator of more than −90 dBm), constraining the operational range between the diver and machine (Supplementary Fig. 37). To enable practical real-time control of submerged robots, it is feasible to use Bluetooth of higher transmitting power, integrate a higher-gain, more directional antenna, and, most importantly, embed the receiving and processing unit within the submerged robot. This configuration would allow direct communication between the wearable sensors and the robots, which can eliminate the need for an intermediate system for signal acquisition, processing and robotic arm control, thereby decreasing the signal transmission loss and extending communication range. In addition, it is possible to integrate radio waves (integrated circuits for Bluetooth and Wi-Fi, which is robust for communication at the air/water interface52), acoustic waves (advanced microelectromechanical systems with long transmission ranges53) and optical methods (tunable vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers and photodetectors with high transmission speeds54; Supplementary Note 20 and Supplementary Table 3). Finally, the deep-learning model was not applied to process EMG signals in this study because the two-finger robotic gripper was designed solely for grasping and releasing. To enable fine-motor control and high-resolution gesture recognition, a multi-electrode EMG array would be required to capture spatially distinct signals from individual muscle groups55. Integrating such an array with a multimodal deep-learning model would greatly enhance the system's capacity to decode complex gestures. Alternatively, the EMG module could be replaced by an ultrasound-based system56, which has demonstrated superior capability in capturing high-resolution muscle dynamics and enabling the execution of intricate tasks with greater degrees of freedom. Several glass slides were thoroughly cleaned using acetone, isopropyl alcohol (IPA) and deionized water. Then, 2 glass slides were spin-coated with polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA, 950 A4, MicroChem) at 2,000 rpm for 30 s, followed by curing on a hotplate at 150 °C for 3 min to form a release layer. A layer of Ecoflex (00-30 Smooth-On, 1:1) was spin-coated over the PMMA at 2,000 rpm for 30 s and cured in an oven at 80 °C for 15 min. Subsequently, 3 glass slides were spin-coated with polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS, Sylgard 184 silicone elastomer, 10:1) at 2,000 rpm for 30 s, followed by curing on a hotplate at 150 °C for 20 min. Separately, polyimide (PI, HD MicroSystems) was spin-coated onto Cu foils (Oak-Mitsui) at 2,000 rpm for 30 s, followed by soft baking on a hotplate at 150 °C for 3 min and hard baking in a nitrogen-protected oven at 300 °C for 1 h. The PI-coated Cu film and the PDMS-coated glass slide were activated by ultraviolet ozone (254 nm, PSD series Digital UV Ozone System, Novascan) for 1 min. Subsequently, the PI-coated Cu film was laminated onto the PDMS-coated glass slide and then patterned using pulsed laser ablation (60% power, 10 cycles, Laser Mark's) according to a design created in AutoCAD. After removing residual materials on the patterned Cu film, it was lifted off using a water-soluble tape (AQUASOL), activated by ultraviolet ozone for 3 min, transferred onto the Ecoflex/PMMA-coated glass slide, and then placed in an oven at 80 °C for 10 min to enhance the bonding between the PI and the Ecoflex57. Next, the water-soluble tape was removed by rinsing with deionized water. After drying, the Cu film was cleaned by flux (IMPRESA) to remove the oxide surface and improve the wettability of solder paste (SMDLTLFP, Chip Quik). The solder paste was applied onto the patterned Cu film, followed by bonding the chips to the Cu film on a hotplate at 240 °C for 1 min. Then another layer of Ecoflex was spin-coated at 2,000 rpm and cured on top of the first circuit layer as the substrate for fabricating the second layer. Laser ablation was applied to remove the Ecoflex at designed locations, forming vertical interconnect accesses to interconnect the first and second circuit layers32. Subsequently, the second layer was fabricated atop the Ecoflex substrate with identical processes to the first layer. The microcontroller unit was pre-programmed using a customized evaluation board. The third layer was first fabricated on a new Ecoflex/PMMA-coated glass slide. It was then flipped over and aligned with the first and second layers through alignment markers observed under a microscope. The second and third layers were electrically connected by soldering 0 Ω resistors on a hotplate at 240 °C for 5 min. Finally, the trilayer circuit was encapsulated by filling degassed Ecoflex between the 2 glass slides that sandwiched the circuit, followed by curing at 80 °C for 20 min. The PMMA-coated glass slides were removed by IPA. The Cu layer was fabricated following the same procedure as for the circuit. Subsequently, CNTs (4 wt%) were ground and blended homogeneously with PDMS. IPA was added to further enhance the uniformity of the mixture58. We chose PDMS over Ecoflex because its lower curing rate, which allowed extended stirring time to ensure a more uniform dispersion of CNTs. In addition, PDMS and CNTs were partially soluble in IPA59, which could further enhance the uniformity of the mixture. The CNT-doped PDMS mixture was degassed and evenly spread over the glass slide with the Cu layer. Another PMMA-coated glass slide was then uniformly pressed atop to form a thin CNTs-doped PDMS film, then cured at 80 °C for 2 h. The underlying PI and Ecoflex layers at the circuit connection regions were removed using laser ablation with a power of 10%, enabling subsequent bonding to the circuit via solder paste. Finally, degassed Ecoflex was introduced into the interstitial spaces between the electrodes and the circuit to bond them together. Four inks were formulated to print the stretchable battery: Ag, Zn, Ag2O and TiO2 (ref. 60). The Ag ink was used for the current collector, which was formulated by mixing Ag flakes, poly(styrene–ethylene–butylene–styrene) (SEBS) resin and toluene (4:2:1 weight ratio). The Zn ink was for the battery anode and was synthesized using Zn, ZnO, Bi2O3 and GBR6005 binder (25 wt% mixed in acetone) with a weight ratio of 9:0.5:0.5:0.267. The Ag2O ink was prepared as the battery cathode using Ag2O, Super P carbon black and GBR6005 fluoroelastomer (33 wt% mixed in acetone) with a weight ratio of 1.9:0.1:2.66. The TiO2 ink was prepared as the separator using TiO2, Triton X-114, SEBS (40 wt% mixed in toluene) and toluene with a weight ratio of 3:0.1:1.5:1.5. Each ink was mixed separately in a planetary mixer at 2,500 rpm for 10 min. To prepare the electrolyte, 0.9 g polyvinyl acetate (PVA) was dissolved in 9.1 ml deionized water at 90 °C. This solution was then mixed with 14 g NaOH solution (16.7 wt%) and desiccated to ~67% of its original weight, yielding a PVA hydrogel. The PVA hydrogel was then cut into the designed shape to form the electrolyte gel, followed by soaking in a 9 M NaOH solution containing 0.5 M LiOH for 12 h (ref. 61). The battery was printed layer by layer in the sequence of Ag, Zn anode or double-layered Ag2O cathode (to enhance the capacity), and TiO2 separator, followed by curing at 80 °C for 5 min for each layer. Before assembly, the PVA hydrogel was placed between the anode and the cathode. Two batteries were connected in series using the Ag ink and subsequently heat-sealed with a SEBS film. Finally, the battery was adhered to the underside of the circuit and the fabric substrate using Silbione (Gel 4717 A/B, Bluestar Silicone). Electrical continuity between the battery and the circuit was established by Ag paste (8331DA/B, MG Chemicals). Charging was performed by contacting the two ports with two external needle electrodes, which allowed for minimal invasion of the device's encapsulation. The power consumption of the sensors was characterized using a power profiler kit (Nordic). Electrochemical cycling was conducted using an Arbin electrochemical cycler channel at 0.2 C over 60 cycles under freestanding, bending and stretching conditions (Fig. 1c). Cut-off voltages were 2.6 V (discharge) and 3.8 V (charge). Moreover, we assessed the long-term stability of the hydrogel within the battery by placing it on a hotplate maintained at 37 °C and monitoring its weight loss over time (Extended Data Fig. 1). To assess the battery's practical performance, we connected it to both the circuit and a battery test system (Landt Instruments CT2001A) to monitor voltage variations over time. To simulate skin temperature, the battery was concurrently placed on a hotplate maintained at 37 °C (Supplementary Fig. 7). The commercial software ABAQUS was used to predict constrained deformations and evaluate the stretchability of serpentine interconnects within each layer (Extended Data Fig. 2). Two-layer Cu/PI laminates were modelled using four-node two-dimensional shell elements62. An explicit solver was employed to ensure convergence in simulations involving intricate contact interactions associated with the serpentine interconnects. Cu was characterized using an ideal elastic-plastic constitutive model featuring an elastic modulus of 119 GPa, a Poisson's ratio of 0.34 and a yield strength of 356 MPa (~0.3% yield strain). The mechanical behaviour of the elastomer (Ecoflex), used for encapsulation and as the substrate, was modelled using a typical hyperelastic constitutive relation. This elastomer exhibited an elastic modulus of 50 kPa and a Poisson's ratio of 0.49. For PI, an elastic modulus of 2.5 GPa and a Poisson's ratio of 0.27 were used. A rigid and frictionless contact model described interactions between the serpentine interconnects and electronic components. In addition, fixed boundary conditions were imposed on the two vertical edges of the model. Under uniaxial loading, the displacement components were prescribed as follows: (ux = 0, uz = 0) for the left side and (ux = εappLx, uz = 0) for the right side, where εapp is the overall strain applied to the model and Lx is the length of the model along the x direction. The Bluetooth signal was characterized using the received signal strength indicator. Measurements were conducted through the BLE Scanner software in an open environment. To ensure data accuracy and reliability, the received signal strength indicator value was recorded 15 times under each specified condition (Fig. 1d, Extended Data Fig. 3 and Supplementary Fig. 37). Thermal images were captured by a thermal camera (FLIR, C-Series) after activating the sensors. Images were recorded every 1 min to monitor temperature variations (Fig. 1e and Supplementary Fig. 4). The testing was conducted in air and sensors were deactivated after 30 min. To assess actual wearing conditions, a thermocouple (Sigma) was placed between the active sensors and the skin to monitor temperature continuously during sensor operation (Supplementary Fig. 4). Raw EMG signals are often susceptible to low-frequency motion artefacts63 and 60 Hz power line noise64. To mitigate these interferences, we used a digital 30–200 Hz bandpass filter and a 60 Hz notch filter. The root mean square (RMS) value of the EMG signals was calculated by65,66: where n represents the length of the EMG signal and EMG(i) denotes the magnitude of the ith data point. The RMS value is the average power of the EMG signal over a defined duration: a shorter duration for analysis will increase times of computation and thus the computation load, whereas longer ones capture more bursts of muscle activity but reduce temporal resolution67. In this study, we chose n = 200 to achieve a balance. When the RMS value exceeded 0.2 mV, the robotic gripper performed grasping and, conversely, remained releasing when the value was below the threshold (Fig. 4b and Extended Data Figs. 7–10). To account for inter-individual variations in muscle tone, which can influence EMG signal amplitudes36, we implemented an individual-specific threshold calibration strategy to reliably distinguish hand grasping from releasing65. Specifically, for each new individual, EMG signals were recorded during both grasping and releasing actions (each lasting ~2 s) over 10 cycles. The RMS values of the baseline during releasing (Vbaseline) and grasping (VEMG) were measured. The threshold for the voltage (Vthreshold) was determined as: This calibration ensures consistent recognition performance across individuals with varying EMG signal characteristics. The conductivity (resistance) of the electrode was measured with a digital multimeter (Keysight). Impedance was measured using a bioimpedance analyser (EVAL-AD5940BIOZ) in a three-electrode configuration (that is, working, reference and counter electrodes). All characterizations were conducted under sitting, running and vibration conditions (Supplementary Fig. 11). The performance of the EMG electrode was further evaluated by quantifying the signal-to-noise ratio during sitting, running and vibration (Supplementary Fig. 11). In each test, the individual performed hand releasing and grasping (grip force of ~60 N). The impedance at the electrode–skin interface was measured using a PalmSens4 potentiostat with a three-electrode configuration (Supplementary Fig. 3). The reference electrode maintains a stable potential. This setup enabled precise characterization of the impedance at the working electrode–skin interface, while the counter electrode completes the circuit68. The 3 electrodes were laminated onto the forearm with a 2 cm spacing. We utilized the galvanostatic impedance spectroscopy technique, which applied an alternating current amplitude of 1 μA (iac = 0.01 × 100 μA), across a frequency range from 0.1 Hz to 10 kHz, to ensure safety for the body. To simulate underwater conditions, the electrode–skin interface was submerged in seawater collected from the San Diego Mission Bay. To evaluate the sensors' sensitivity and long-term performance under intensive activities, we conducted tests over five consecutive days. The sensors were mounted on the individual's forearm, where the IMU module recorded motion signals induced by running and the EMG module recorded signals generated by hand grasping. The signal stability was analysed across days using power spectrum density analysis (Supplementary Fig. 12). Performance under varying temperature and humidity conditions was assessed by analysing baseline noise levels. The sensors were placed on a hotplate at different temperatures while kept stationary. In addition, the sensors were tested in an enclosed room where humidity levels were adjusted using a humidifier (Supplementary Fig. 13). To characterize the effect of perspiration on signal quality, EMG measurements were performed at 0 min, 15 min and 30 min after treadmill running. In each scenario, the individual performed hand releasing and grasping (grip force of ~60 N; Supplementary Fig. 14). The individual first performed each gesture 20 times while sitting. Each signal was subsequently superimposed with 18 different motion artefacts, including running, vibration and their combinations at different stages, with a duration of 1 s (Fig. 3a and Extended Data Fig. 4). To address the influence of orientation changes on the baseline and morphology of the gesture signals, each gesture was also performed 20 times while lying down. These signals were superimposed with six motion artefacts related to vibration (without those from running) (Supplementary Fig. 15). All superimposed signals used in the training dataset were unique and non-repetitive (which accommodates variability in both gesture signals and motion artefacts), thereby preventing the model from overfitting owing to memorizing recurring patterns. In addition, to reduce the orientation discrepancies between the superimposed signals and the real gesture signals collected under different motion artefacts (versus those signals obtained by superimposing motion artefacts with gesture signals for training), we adopted two measures: first, during the collection of motion artefacts (for example, running), the individual maintained a palm-down posture, matching the orientation used during real-world gesture execution. Second, we filtered out the baseline component from the acceleration signals in the motion artefacts before superposition (note that angular velocities do not have baselines generated by gravity), which reduces the influence of static orientation, thereby aligning the superimposed signals with those of real-world gesture signals recorded under motion artefacts. For transfer learning, we collected a training dataset from 6 volunteers with consent (5 males and 1 female, aged 21 to 34) with different movement characteristics and forearm lengths (40–50 cm). The datasets from five individuals were used to train the CNN, while the sixth dataset was used for fine-tuning and testing. During the fine-tuning process, we trained the CNN with one to four shots to determine the optimal shot number. Subsequently, 100 unused signals were randomly selected to evaluate the performance of the CNN (Fig. 3e and Extended Data Fig. 5). This ensured a strict separation between training and testing datasets, thereby preventing any potential data during training. Each superimposed signal was concatenated with 19 other superimposed signals (including both identical and other different gestures), which produced 342 concatenated signals (19 superimposed signals with 18 or 6 stages of motion artefacts for sitting or lying down postures, respectively), each spanning 2 s. Then, a sliding window segmented each concatenated signal into 5, yielding a total of 2,280 segmented signals with motion artefacts (Fig. 3f, Extended Data Fig. 6 and Supplementary Fig. 24). In total, 2,470 signals were generated per gesture, comprising 95 segmented signals from sitting and 95 from lying down without motion artefacts, along with 2,280 segmented signals with motion artefacts. Across all 19 gestures, a total of 46,930 signals were generated per individual. The dataset was split into training, validation and testing datasets at a ratio of 70%: 15%: 15%. Performance was evaluated across 15 independent runs. To ensure consistency in sensor orientation, the individual maintained a palm-down orientation during the robotic control. This configuration was necessary because six gestures involved the palm (that is, wrist rotations). Maintaining a consistent orientation minimized potential misclassification by the model. IMU and EMG signals from the wearable sensors were transmitted to a USB receiver and processed by MATLAB on a desktop computer. The six-channel IMU signals were continuously segmented using a 1 s sliding window (0.25 s step) and then sent to an online trained CNN in Python. Windows shorter than 1 s were discarded. The gesture was chosen after three consecutive identical predictions, after which the count reset to prevent repetition. The predicted results were subsequently sent back to MATLAB to control the robotic arm, which executed commands continuously without reverting to the original state. In the meantime, the EMG signals were acquired and filtered in MATLAB to control the grasping and releasing of the robotic gripper based on the RMS values. The communication between Python and MATLAB was through the TCP/IP protocol (Supplementary Fig. 27). In demonstrations, the beaker was at a fixed location to ensure controlled comparison of gesture signals under different motion artefacts, but the robotic arm can accurately grasp objects placed anywhere within the workspace. The sensors were encased within a plastic enclosure and positioned within the water channel of the Scripps Ocean–Atmosphere Research Simulator (Fig. 5b and Supplementary Fig. 30). Throughout the data-acquisition phase, the sensors remained afloat on the water surface, which emulated a diver floating in the ocean. Sea waves were generated by a paddle, with the frequency adjusted to vary wavelength (Supplementary Fig. 32) and the force adjusted to control height (Supplementary Fig. 33). Further information on research design is available in the Nature Research Reporting Summary linked to this article. The data and material resources supporting the findings of this study are available within the article and its Supplementary Information. The raw data can be found in the Source Data files. Google Scholar Search author on:PubMed Google Scholar Search author on:PubMed Google Scholar X.C., Z.L. and S.X. designed the research. X.C., X.G., M.L., S.Q, F.Z., Y.L., S.D., R.L. and S.T. fabricated the sensors. Z.L., X.G., Z.Z. and R.S. designed the deep learning algorithms. X.C., Z.L., Y.L. and S.X. analysed the data. X.C., Z.L., X.G. and S.X. wrote the paper. All authors provided constructive and valuable feedback on the paper. Correspondence to Joseph Wang or Sheng Xu. The authors declare no competing interests. Nature Sensors thanks Chi Hwan Lee and the other, anonymous, reviewer(s) for their contribution to the peer review of this work. Publisher's note Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations. a, Undeformed. b, 25% Stretching. c, Twisting. d, Bending. Owing to its soft constituent materials, the battery exhibits remarkable durability under extensive mechanical deformations. e, Output voltage stability under cyclic mechanical deformations. The output voltage remained steady at ~3.1 V with minimal fluctuation. f, Long-term stability test of the hydrogel within the battery. The hydrogel exhibits excellent stability due to its enclosed nature, with negligible weight loss observed over five days when the battery is placed on a hotplate maintained at 37 °C. Source data a, Photos of the sensors under horizontal 100-cycle stretchability test from 0 to 20%. b, Photos of the sensors under vertical 100-cycle stretchability test from 0 to 20%. c, Finite element analysis of each layer in the sensors under 25% uniaxial stretching. The analysis confirms that the maximum strain does not exceed 0.3%, indicating that the Cu electrodes remain well within their elastic limit and do not yield or undergo plastic deformation. To mitigate computational load, mechanical simulations were performed on individual layers rather than the entire assembly. In the actual sensors, vertical interconnect accesses between layers can lead to localized strain concentrations when stretched. Consequently, the simulations assumed a higher stretchability (25%) than the cyclic mechanical test (20%). a, Photos of the sensors under simultaneous 100-cycle tensile forces along both vertical and horizontal directions from 0 to 20%. The sensors exhibit no plastic deformation after 300 cycles of biaxial stretching tests, which demonstrates the robustness of the design. b, Bluetooth signal strength under bi-axial stretching. The RSSI consistently remained above -60 dBm across all tested strain levels, indicating stable and continuous wireless communication. Two competing effects influence signal strength during stretching. First, mechanical strain increases the resistance of the interconnections, leading to higher transmission loss (that is, reduced signal strength). Second, as the device stretches, the antenna becomes progressively more distant from nearby electronic components, reducing parasitic capacitance and thereby decreasing signal loss (that is, improved signal strength). Due to these opposing effects, the signal strength initially decreases from increased resistance and subsequently increases as parasitic loss diminishes. The graph presents the average values, with error bars indicating the standard deviation (n = 15 independent measurements). Source data a, 20 signals of gesture 2 recorded while sitting. b, Motion artefacts induced by running. These motion artefacts are divided into six stages with each stage lasting 1 s. c, Motion artefacts induced by high-frequency vibrations. These motion artefacts are divided into six stages with each stage lasting 1 s. d, Motion artefacts induced by the combination of high-frequency vibrations and running. These motion artefacts are divided into six stages with each stage lasting 1 s. e, Superimposed signals for training. The superimposed signals are generated by adding motion areifacts to the gesture signal (for example, a signal of gesture 2 superimposed with 18 stages of motion artefacts in b to d). The stages are fixed rather than chosen by randomly selecting starting points from continuous motion artefact recordings. Since random selection can unintentionally introduce overlapping segments, where identical portions of motion artefacts appear in multiple superimposed signals. This redundancy may lead to overfitting, because the model may learn to recognize repeated motion artefact patterns rather than extracting generalizable features. To mitigate this risk, we deliberately divided the motion artefacts into distinct, non-overlapping stages. Source data Confusion matrices of the prediction results based on a, one-shot, b, three-shot, and c, four-shot transfer learning for gesture recognition. In one-shot transfer learning, the minimum observed accuracy is 69% for gesture 15, which is considered suboptimal. This limitation is attributed to the fact that a single gesture signal is obtained from a individual in only one posture: either sitting or lying down. When two or more shots are used in transfer learning, gesture signals during both sitting and lying down are collected. As a result, the recognition accuracy can stabilize and converge. Therefore, two-shot transfer learning has been adopted because it balances the time for collecting gesture signals and the accuracy (Fig. 3e). Source data a, 19 concatenated signals (for example, superimposed with running motion artefacts). These signals are generated by connecting one superimposed signal end-to-end with 19 different types of superimposed signals. b, Each concatenated gesture signal can generate five segmented signals by the sliding window. Each segmented signal is labeled based on the gesture signal that occupies more than 50% of the window duration. Source data The individual utilizes a muscle massage gun to generate high-frequency motion artefacts. Leveraging the trained CNN, the system achieves precise prediction accuracy for controlling the robotic arm. Furthermore, the robotic gripper can perform accurate grasping and releasing actions based on EMG signals. A glass vial is grasped and moved to a designated location accurately to pour water into a beaker. Source data The change in posture results in distinct IMU signal waveforms, attributed to the variations in orientation relative to gravity. Utilizing the trained CNN, the system maintains high prediction accuracy during robotic arm control. A glass vial is grasped and moved to a designated location accurately to pour water into a beaker. Source data Utilizing the trained CNN, the system maintains high prediction accuracy in controlling the robotic arm even while the individual is lying down and experiencing high-frequency vibrations simultaneously. A glass vial is grasped and moved to a designated location accurately to pour water into a beaker. Source data Utilizing the trained CNN, the system maintains high prediction accuracy in controlling the robotic arm even when the individual is running and experiencing high-frequency vibrations. A glass vial is grasped and moved to a designated location accurately to pour water into a beaker. Source data Supplementary Notes 1–20, Figs. 1–37 and Video legends 1–7. Robotic arm control during running. Robotic arm control during running using the trained CNN. Robotic arm control during high-frequency vibrations. Robotic arm control during lying down. Robotic arm control during lying down and high-frequency vibrations. Robotic arm control during running and high-frequency vibrations. Sea wave motion artifacts collection in SOARS. Home Depot's Black Friday Sales on Drills are Pretty Good—But the Deals at Lowe's Are Better
Source: Popular Mechanics    Published: 2025-11-17 05:00:00

We spent hours comparing discounts at both retailers, and there's one clear winner. Gear-obsessed editors choose every product we review. We may earn commission if you buy from a link. Why Trust Us? Home improvement weekend warriors rejoice! If you've been waiting all year to pull the trigger on purchasing a new cordless drill or drill/driver, Black Friday deals are here. But you might be wondering: where to start your shopping? Both Lowe's and Home Depot have similar selections when it comes to these power tools (not to mention their large appliances like refrigerators and washing machines, which are also impressively discounted.) But which store will save you the most money on a drill this Black Friday? We searched extensively, and this is what we found. Shop Black Friday Deals at Lowe's Shop Black Friday Deals at Home Depot The biggest reason I give the edge to Lowe's over Home Depot is based on how its drill deals are structured. At Home Depot, the most value you'll get from its sales on power tools (and especially drills) hinges on buying additional items with a purchase. For instance, buying a Ryobi battery starter kit would include a free tool of your choice. This is no doubt tantalizing for some, but I'm more inclined to get truly excited about a sale if I'm saving actual dollars on the thing I want most. Most people looking for a new drill need just that: a new drill. Sometimes, you might like an extra battery pack, but if your cordless tool collection is extensive, you probably have more than enough batteries. If deals in the form of dollars saved is where your head is this Black Friday, this deal from Lowe's on the DeWalt cordless drill does just that. No bundles or add-ons. Just a high-quality drill that costs $60 less than the standard retail price. We also like this option from Craftsman because it strips away all the extra fluff. Instead of paying more money for more items at a great overall discount percentage, we like the idea of getting a quality item at the most affordable price, regardless of any other factors. While $30 off might not make your eyes pop, the key point is you're only spending 70 bucks. In contrast, the best driver deal we found at Home Depot maximizes total savings but ends up giving you more than you might need at a bigger discount. The Milwaukee driver combo kit is on sale for a notable 41 percent off, which is certainly nothing to scoff at. However, the kit has both a drill driver and impact driver in it, as well as a couple of batteries. While nice if you are starting from scratch, even the heavily slashed price is still going to run you for more than just buying the exact item you need at sale price from Lowe's. Listen, there isn't really a wrong answer when shopping this holiday season. Black Friday sales shave off enough that you won't exactly get hosed no matter which site you end up shopping at. Our main point is that we prefer hard dollars off and individual items over bundles and combos purchases. It may not lead to the flashiest headlines, but it almost certainly means you'll spend less overall at checkout. Tom Price is a reviews editor for Popular Mechanics while also contributing to Runner's World, Best Products, and Bicycling. Here at Popular Mechanics, Tom loves testing out home appliances, smart tech, gear for city life and outdoor adventures, small gadgets like watches and multitools, and anything else you can find piled up at his hoarder's nest of a desk. Prior to working here, Tom attended NYU, graduating with a degree in English and a minor in creative writing. He also wrote for Best Reviews, The Daily Beast, and other publications covering tech, fitness gear, gadgets, and lifestyle products. Furthermore, he covered startup news, pop culture, and even professional wrestling. To follow more of his work, check back here for new stories. GLP-1 drugs like Ozempic deliver huge weight loss but new research reveals a hidden catch
Source: ScienceDaily    Published: 2025-11-17 03:41:31

Three new Cochrane reviews report that GLP-1 drugs can lead to meaningful weight loss, although the strong involvement of pharmaceutical companies in many studies raises concerns. The World Health Organization (WHO) requested these reviews to help shape upcoming recommendations on using these medications for obesity treatment. The analyses evaluated three GLP-1 receptor agonists used for weight management and found that each one produced clinically important weight loss when compared with placebo. Even so, there is still limited or uncertain evidence about their long-term safety, possible side effects, and how financial ties might influence study results. Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists were first introduced in the mid-2000s to help people with type 2 diabetes. In that setting, particularly among those with underlying heart or kidney disease, the drugs helped improve blood sugar levels, lowered the risk of related complications, aided weight reduction, and reduced the likelihood of early death. More recently, researchers have been testing GLP-1 receptor agonists in people with obesity. These medications work by imitating a natural hormone that slows digestion and helps individuals feel full for longer. In the United Kingdom, they are approved for weight management when combined with a reduced calorie diet and physical activity for people with obesity or for those who are overweight with related health issues. GLP-1 drugs show promise for weight management Across the reviewed studies, tirzepatide, semaglutide, and liraglutide consistently led to significant weight loss over one to two years compared with placebo, and the benefits appeared to continue during ongoing treatment. The reviews found little to no difference between the drugs and placebo when looking at major cardiovascular events, mortality, or quality of life. However, nausea and digestive discomfort appeared more often among people taking GLP-1 drugs, and some participants discontinued treatment because of these side effects. "These drugs have the potential to bring about substantial weight loss, particularly in the first year," says Juan Franco, co-lead researcher from Heinrich Heine University Düsseldorf, Germany. "It's an exciting moment after decades of unsuccessful attempts to find effective treatments for people living with obesity." Independent research and equitable access are key Most of the studies included in the reviews were funded by the companies that manufacture the drugs and were shaped by those companies in terms of design, analysis, and reporting. This has raised questions about potential conflicts of interest and highlights the importance of independent research. The authors also stressed that the use of these medications should be viewed in a broader health context, including issues such as access, affordability, and insurance coverage, so that existing health inequities are not made worse. Costs remain a major barrier, particularly for semaglutide and tirzepatide, while liraglutide has become more affordable since its patent expired. Semaglutide's patent is set to expire in 2026. Most of the trials were conducted in middle- and high-income countries, with little or no representation from regions such as Africa, Central America, and Southeast Asia. Because body composition, eating patterns, and health behaviors differ around the world, the authors emphasized the need to understand how these drugs work in more diverse populations. "We need more data on the long-term effects and other outcomes related to cardiovascular health, particularly in lower-risk individuals," says Eva Madrid, co-lead researcher from the Universidad de Valparaíso, Chile. "Weight regain after stopping treatment may affect the long-term sustainability of the observed benefits. More independent studies from a public health perspective are needed." The reviews highlight the need for long-term, independent investigations to guide clinical and policy decisions and to better define the role of GLP-1 receptor agonists in lasting weight management. Commissioned by the World Health Organization, the reviews will contribute to upcoming WHO guidelines on the use of GLP-1 receptor agonists for treating obesity. Story Source: Materials provided by Cochrane. Note: Content may be edited for style and length. Journal Reference: Cite This Page: Scientists Discover a Diet That Can Prevent and Reverse a Key Type of Heart Disease Scientists Create “Key” To Find Alien Life in Clouds Our Solar System Is Moving 3x Faster Than Scientists Expected Satellites Spot 115 Foot “Monster” Waves From Pacific Megastorm Stay informed with ScienceDaily's free email newsletter, updated daily and weekly. Or view our many newsfeeds in your RSS reader: Keep up to date with the latest news from ScienceDaily via social networks: Tell us what you think of ScienceDaily -- we welcome both positive and negative comments. Have any problems using the site? Questions?
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


TECHNOLOGY

Scientists create a supercomputer simulation that can reveal how the brain works, neuron by neuron
Source: GeekWire    Published: 2025-11-17 19:11:23

GeekWire Gala: Last chance for early bird tix! by Alan Boyle on Nov 17, 2025 at 11:11 amNovember 17, 2025 at 11:11 am Creating a virtual brain may sound like a science-fiction nightmare, but for neuroscientists in Japan and at Seattle's Allen Institute, it's a big step toward a long-held dream. They say their mouse-cortex simulation, run on one of the world's fastest supercomputers, could eventually open the way to understanding the mechanisms behind maladies such as Alzheimer's disease and epilepsy — and perhaps unraveling the mysteries of consciousness. “This shows the door is open,” Allen Institute investigator Anton Arkhipov said today in a news release. “It's a technical milestone giving us confidence that much larger models are not only possible, but achievable with precision and scale.” Arkhipov and his colleagues describe the project in a research paper being presented this week in St. Louis during the SC25 conference on high-performance computing. The simulation models the activity of a whole mouse cortex, encompassing nearly 10 million neurons connected by 26 billion synapses. To create the simulation, researchers fed data from the Allen Cell Types Database and the Allen Connectivity Atlas into Supercomputer Fugaku, a computing cluster developed by Fujitsu and Japan's RIKEN Center for Computational Science. Fugaku is capable of executing more than 400 quadrillion operations per second, or 400 petaflops. The massive data set was translated into a 3-D model using the Allen Institute's Brain Modeling ToolKit. A simulation program called Neulite brought the data to life as virtual neurons that interact with each other like living brain cells. Scientists ran the program in different scenarios, including an experiment that used the full-scale Fugaku configuration to model the entire mouse cortex. “In our simulation, each neuron is modeled as a large tree of interacting compartments — hundreds of compartments per neuron,” Arkhipov said in comments emailed to GeekWire. “That is, we are capturing some sub-cellular structures and dynamics within each neuron.” During the full-scale simulation, it took no more than 32 seconds to simulate one second of real-time activity in a living mouse brain. “This level of performance — 32 times slower than real time — is quite impressive for a system of this size and complexity,” Arkhipov said. “It is not uncommon to see a factor of thousands of times slower for such very detailed simulations (even much smaller than ours).” The researchers acknowledge that much more work is needed to turn their simulation into a model capable of tracing the progress of a neurological disease. For example, the model doesn't reflect brain plasticity — that is, the brain's ability to rewire its own connections. “If we want to mention something specific besides plasticity, then one aspect that is missing is the effects of neuromodulators, and the other is that we currently do not have a very detailed representation of sensory inputs in our whole-cortex simulations,” Arkhipov said. “For all of these, we need much more data than currently available to make much better models, although some approximations or hypotheses could be implemented and tested now that we have a working whole-cortex simulation.” Arkhipov said the project's long-term goal is to simulate an entire brain, not just the cortex. “There's a distinction between whole-cortex and whole-brain,” he pointed out. “The mouse cortex (and our model of it) contains about 10 million neurons, whereas the whole mouse brain contains about 70 million neurons.” A human-brain simulation would require an even greater leap. The human cortex alone contains not just 10 million neurons, but 21 billion. The good news is that a sufficiently powerful supercomputer might be up to the task. “Our work shows that very detailed microscopic-level simulations of larger brains may be possible sooner than previously expected,” Arkhipov said. “The results suggest that a simulation of the whole monkey brain (such as that of a macaque monkey with 6 billion neurons) can fit on the full-scale Fugaku system.” Arkhipov said it was important to point out that creating a brain model on a supercomputer “does not mean that such a model is complete or accurate.” “Here we are talking about technical feasibility of simulations, and it looks like such simulations even at the scale of the monkey brain are now within reach,” he said. “But to make such simulations biologically realistic, much more experimental data production and model building work would need to happen.” Rin Kuriyama and Kaaya Akira of the University of Electro-Communications in Tokyo are the principal authors of the paper presented at SC25, titled “Microscopic-Level Mouse Whole Cortex Simulation Composed of 9 Million Biophysical Neurons and 26 Billion Synapses on the Supercomputer Fugaku.” In addition to Arkhipov, authors from the Allen Institute include Laura Green, Beatriz Herrera and Kael Dai. The study's other authors are Tadashi Yamazaki and Mari Iura of the University of Electro-Communications; Gilles Gouaillardet and Asako Terasawa of the Research Organization for Information Science and Technology in Hyogo, Japan; Taira Kobayashi of Yamaguchi University; and Jun Igarashi of the RIKEN Center for Computational Science. Cloud moves fast, don't get left behind. AWS re:Invent connects you with global leaders, builders, and innovators. Get hands-on training, learn from experts, and network with peers. Explore the latest tech, discover breakthrough solutions, and take your cloud journey further. Don't just keep pace—lead the way. Register now. Peter Thiel Is Reportedly Dumping Nvidia Stock Amid AI Bubble Jitters
Source: Gizmodo    Published: 2025-11-17 18:05:49

Reading time 2 minutes Peter Thiel is the latest investor to sell off Nvidia shares. According to regulatory filings, the billionaire's hedge fund, Thiel Macro, has offloaded its entire stake in Nvidia. The firm has sold 537,742 shares in its third quarter, which would have been worth around $100 million, according to Reuters estimates. There are many reasons why investors might decide to sell off their stake in a company, and not all of those reasons are worth giant alarm bells. But it does pique interest when those stakes belong to the world's most valuable company, and the decision comes mere days after another high-profile investor selloff. Just last week, prominent Japanese investor SoftBank shared that it sold its entire stake in the chipmaker. The firm said that it raked in $5.83 billion from the sale of 32.1 million Nvidia shares in October. The sale was apparently made to fund a multibillion-dollar investment in OpenAI, on top of the billions the firm has already invested in the tech giant. SoftBank and OpenAI are also partners under the Trump-backed data center build-out plan known as Stargate. Nvidia is considered the ultimate AI darling. It's a company that hit $5 trillion market value by riding the AI wave, and it holds a central position in the industry as the primary global supplier of highly coveted AI chips. As a result, any perceived distrust in Nvidia's trajectory is taken as a negative sign for the AI industry overall. It's not entirely certain what Thiel and SoftBank's sell-offs confidently signal about overall investor sentiment regarding artificial intelligence, and whether or not there is indeed an AI bubble, but it sure is adding on top of readily existing worries, and making people feel queasy. Over the past few months, a growing chorus of experts, from the Bank of England to investor Michael Burry of The Big Short fame, have been warning against an AI bubble that could bring not just the market but possibly the entire American economy down with it if it bursts. Companies, like Nvidia, have hit record valuations as investors are delighted by the potential gains that AI represents. But some believe that investor appetite is FOMO-driven and could be artificially inflating the actual value of these companies. Even some top tech executives like Sam Altman and Jeff Bezos have admitted to overvaluation. So what happens when that investor appetite just stops? All eyes are now on Nvidia's earnings report later this week to shed more light on whether the news from the past week is part of a newly forming trend that warrants worry or just a fluke. The tech giant will be reporting third-quarter earnings results after the bell on Wednesday. Explore more on these topics Share this story Subscribe and interact with our community, get up to date with our customised Newsletters and much more. Gadgets gifts are the best gifts to get friends and family. Windows Copilot can't even tell users how to correctly resize their text. Bezos' new company is a mysterious physical AI venture You can't keep a good Karp down. More and more people want to make it official with their computer-generated lovers. "Sometimes, the only winning move is not to play." ©2025 GIZMODO USA LLC. All rights reserved.
